articles.headline: Hotelier’s Push for $126 Million in Small-Business Aid Draws Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Monty Bennett says the government should help companies like his. Now, Senator Chuck Schumer is asking for a review of use of the Paycheck Protection Program by Mr. Bennett’s companies.
articles.abstract: Monty Bennett says the government should help companies like his. Now, Senator Chuck Schumer is asking for a review of use of the Paycheck Protection Program by Mr. Bennett’s companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monty Bennett’s sprawling hospitality company is the biggest known applicant of the government’s small-business relief program. The Texas conservative has remained unwilling to return his loans even as public anger builds over large companies getting the funds — a fact now drawing the scrutiny of a key lawmaker.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Drive-Throughs Are Now a Lifeline for Fast-Food Chains
articles.snippet: With dine-in restaurants shuttered and social distancing paramount, drive-throughs are now providing a crucial source of revenue during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: With dine-in restaurants shuttered and social distancing paramount, drive-throughs are now providing a crucial source of revenue during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the fast-food drive-through has been a greasy symbol of Americana, a roadside ritual for millions of travelers with a hankering for burgers and fries.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Colleges Won’t Refund Tuition. Autumn May Force a Reckoning.
articles.snippet: Educators at schools from Brown to Northern Arizona know the experience is lacking. So why won’t they give some money back?
articles.abstract: Educators at schools from Brown to Northern Arizona know the experience is lacking. So why won’t they give some money back?
articles.lead_paragraph: If you didn’t get what you paid for, and the thing you bought cost five figures, it stands to reason that you’d get some of your money back.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: As Businesses Resurface After State Shutdowns, So Does Divisiveness
articles.snippet: Nearly a dozen states resumed portions of public life as a debate over the safety and timing of reopening grew louder.
articles.abstract: Nearly a dozen states resumed portions of public life as a debate over the safety and timing of reopening grew louder.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Texas lifted stay-at-home orders for its 29 million residents. Hair salons in Maine welcomed customers back inside. In Alabama, clothing boutiques flung open their doors.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Sarah Mervosh

articles.headline: ‘I Could Solve Most of Your Problems’: Eric Schmidt’s Pentagon Offensive
articles.snippet: The former Google C.E.O. has reinvented himself as the prime liaison between Silicon Valley and the military-industrial complex.
articles.abstract: The former Google C.E.O. has reinvented himself as the prime liaison between Silicon Valley and the military-industrial complex.
articles.lead_paragraph: In July 2016, Raymond Thomas, a four-star general and head of the U.S. Special Operations Command, hosted a guest: Eric Schmidt, the chairman of Google.
articles.byline: By Kate Conger and Cade Metz

articles.headline: No More Jenga, No More ‘Amen’ as Cities Learn to Live With Coronavirus
articles.snippet: In parts of Asia and Australia, people are going out — but social distancing and other restrictions have become the new normal.
articles.abstract: In parts of Asia and Australia, people are going out — but social distancing and other restrictions have become the new normal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Worshipers at one of Seoul’s largest Catholic churches must refrain from singing hymns or saying “amen” for fear of spreading saliva. Priests sanitize their hands during communion. Holy water has been removed from the chapel.
articles.byline: By Javier C. Hernández and Su-Hyun Lee

articles.headline: Some Small Businesses That Got Aid Fear the Rules Too Much to Spend It
articles.snippet: Requirements for using federal coronavirus loans are complicated and confusing for owners. “It’s chaos,” one lawyer said.
articles.abstract: Requirements for using federal coronavirus loans are complicated and confusing for owners. “It’s chaos,” one lawyer said.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a $192,000 loan from the federal government’s small-business aid program arrived in his bank account last month, George Evageliou, the founder of a custom woodworking company, felt like one of the lucky ones.
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley, Emily Flitter and David Enrich

articles.headline: The Allegation Is Against Joe Biden, but the Burden Is on Women
articles.snippet: Even with the progress of #MeToo, women are called upon to defend their male colleagues. In the 2020 election, that can mean putting the movement itself on the line.
articles.abstract: Even with the progress of #MeToo, women are called upon to defend their male colleagues. In the 2020 election, that can mean putting the movement itself on the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: He may not have been their first choice.
articles.byline: By Jessica Bennett and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: Profits and Pride at Stake, the Race for a Vaccine Intensifies
articles.snippet: Governments, companies and academic labs are accelerating their efforts amid geopolitical crosscurrents, questions about safety and the challenges of producing enough doses for billions of people.
articles.abstract: Governments, companies and academic labs are accelerating their efforts amid geopolitical crosscurrents, questions about safety and the challenges of producing enough doses for billions of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four months after a mysterious new virus began its deadly march around the globe, the search for a vaccine has taken on an intensity never before seen in medical research, with huge implications for public health, the world economy and politics.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, David D. Kirkpatrick, Carl Zimmer, Katie Thomas and Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: ‘We Had to Do Something’: Trying to Prevent Massive Food Waste
articles.snippet: Some producers acknowledge the efforts are “just a drop in the bucket” of what farmers can’t sell and are destroying instead.
articles.abstract: Some producers acknowledge the efforts are “just a drop in the bucket” of what farmers can’t sell and are destroying instead.
articles.lead_paragraph: While millions of Americans are worried about having enough to eat and lines at food banks grow, farmers have been plowing under vegetable fields, dumping milk and smashing eggs that cannot be sold because the coronavirus pandemic has shut down restaurants, hotels and schools.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: One of Amazon’s Most Powerful Critics Lives in Its Backyard
articles.snippet: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington tried to keep her concerns about the company private. Now she’s going public.
articles.abstract: Representative Pramila Jayapal of Washington tried to keep her concerns about the company private. Now she’s going public.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Pramila Jayapal was walking a fine line when she arrived at Amazon’s Seattle headquarters on a chilly day last October to meet with some of the company’s top executives.
articles.byline: By David McCabe

articles.headline: The Covid-19 Riddle: Why Does the Virus Wallop Some Places and Spare Others?
articles.snippet: Experts are trying to figure out why the coronavirus is so capricious. The answers could determine how to best protect ourselves and how long we have to.
articles.abstract: Experts are trying to figure out why the coronavirus is so capricious. The answers could determine how to best protect ourselves and how long we have to.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coronavirus has killed so many people in Iran that the country has resorted to mass burials, but in neighboring Iraq, the body count is fewer than 100.
articles.byline: By Hannah Beech, Alissa J. Rubin, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Ruth Maclean

articles.headline: Why Biden’s Choice of Running Mate Has Momentous Implications
articles.snippet: Joe Biden has hinted that he might serve only one term if he wins. That would set up a woman as the front-runner for 2024 and perhaps define the Democratic agenda for the next decade.
articles.abstract: Joe Biden has hinted that he might serve only one term if he wins. That would set up a woman as the front-runner for 2024 and perhaps define the Democratic agenda for the next decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades the vice-presidential selection process has had an air of cloak-and-dagger to it. The party’s nominees would say little about their thinking, the would-be running mates would reveal even less, and an elaborate game of subterfuge would unfold that mostly captivated political insiders and usually had little bearing on the election.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Warren Buffett’s Optimistic? Pessimistic? No, Realistic
articles.snippet: Between the lines of “You can bet on America” were warnings not to be overconfident in predicting what the future might hold.
articles.abstract: Between the lines of “You can bet on America” were warnings not to be overconfident in predicting what the future might hold.
articles.lead_paragraph: You could always count on the folksy and cheery optimism of Warren Buffett.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Virus Pushes a Staid Supreme Court Into Revolutionary Changes
articles.snippet: The court is set to depart from history twice on Monday: The justices will hear arguments by conference call, and the public will be able to listen in.
articles.abstract: The court is set to depart from history twice on Monday: The justices will hear arguments by conference call, and the public will be able to listen in.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few months ago, a coalition of news organizations asked the Supreme Court to allow live audio coverage of major arguments on gay rights and immigration. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. rejected the request within hours, in keeping with longstanding practice at an institution that almost never departs from tradition.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Before Covid-19, Trump Aide Sought to Use Disease to Close Borders
articles.snippet: The president’s chief adviser on immigration, Stephen Miller, had long tried to halt migration based on public health, without success. Then came the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: The president’s chief adviser on immigration, Stephen Miller, had long tried to halt migration based on public health, without success. Then came the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the early days of the Trump administration, Stephen Miller, the president’s chief adviser on immigration, has repeatedly tried to use an obscure law designed to protect the nation from diseases overseas as a way to tighten the borders.
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: J. Crew Files for Bankruptcy in Virus’s First Big Retail Casualty
articles.snippet: It was struggling before the coronavirus pandemic, but J. Crew is unlikely to be the last retailer to fall.
articles.abstract: It was struggling before the coronavirus pandemic, but J. Crew is unlikely to be the last retailer to fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: J. Crew, the mass-market clothing company whose preppy-with-a-twist products were worn by Michelle Obama and appeared at New York Fashion Week, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday. It is the first major retailer to fall during the coronavirus pandemic, though other big industry names including Neiman Marcus and J.C. Penney are also struggling with the toll of mass shutdowns.
articles.byline: By Vanessa Friedman, Sapna Maheshwari and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: How a New Breed of Union Activists Is Changing the Rules (and Newsrooms)
articles.snippet: Cheered on by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and others, a new generation is making gains on everything from layoff protections to gender-neutral pronouns. Can they help save the industry?
articles.abstract: Cheered on by Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez and others, a new generation is making gains on everything from layoff protections to gender-neutral pronouns. Can they help save the industry?
articles.lead_paragraph: As the coronavirus crisis wreaked havoc in the news business last month, the newly installed president of the most prominent journalists’ union in the country, the NewsGuild, crossed a line that once seemed unimaginable: He asked the government for money.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: A Family Business Survived One Pandemic. It’s Determined to Do It Again.
articles.snippet: A small Buffalo manufacturer has had to trim its staff and spending. But its fourth-generation owner says: “We will take care of everybody.”
articles.abstract: A small Buffalo manufacturer has had to trim its staff and spending. But its fourth-generation owner says: “We will take care of everybody.”
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Robert L. Stevenson gathered his work force at Eastman Machine in Buffalo in mid-March, businesses nationwide were shutting down. But Eastman, which makes fabric-cutting machines, has been in family hands for four generations, and Mr. Stevenson wasn’t about to turn off the lights.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: China’s Coronavirus Vaccine Drive Empowers a Troubled Industry
articles.snippet: By some measures, it is winning the race, with four companies already testing their vaccine candidates on humans.
articles.abstract: By some measures, it is winning the race, with four companies already testing their vaccine candidates on humans.
articles.lead_paragraph: China wants to beat the world in the race to find a coronavirus vaccine — and, by some measures, it is doing just that.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee

articles.headline: As World Comes to Halt Amid Pandemic, So Do Migrants
articles.snippet: Laborers have not just stopped traveling in search of work. Many have also headed back to their home countries.
articles.abstract: Laborers have not just stopped traveling in search of work. Many have also headed back to their home countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A migrant shelter in southern Mexico called La 72 has for years been a popular way station for those traveling from Central America to the United States. Last year it received a record number of visitors, sometimes sheltering more than 2,000 a month.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple
